intro: Porophyllum seemannii, commonly known as the Mexican ironweed, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of Mexico and the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to dry, hot climates. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are small and clustered in dense, spherical inflorescences. Porophyllum seemannii is often used in traditional medicine and has ecological importance as a food source for certain insects.
